title: 108_s579
content:
The curr_chunk is a section header titled "SHORT TITLE." The Act is named the "National Transportation Safety Board Reauthorization Act of 2003." It authorizes specific appropriations for fiscal years 2003-2006, including amounts for each year. Additionally, it allows for additional appropriations to maintain an Emergency Fund up to $4,000,000 and establishes an NTSB Academy. The National Transportation Safety Board Reauthorization Act of 2003 authorizes appropriations for the NTSB Academy, totaling $3,347,000 for 2003, $4,896,000 for 2004, $4,995,000 for 2005, and $5,200,000 for 2006. The Board can impose fees for services provided by the Academy, with collected fees credited as offsetting collections for related expenses. The National Transportation Safety Board Reauthorization Act of 2003 allows for fees to be imposed for services at the NTSB Academy, with collected fees used to cover related costs. The Board has the authority to refund any overpaid fees. Additionally, the Act requires the NTSB to report annually to Congress on the Academy's activities. The National Transportation Safety Board Reauthorization Act of 2003 allows for fees to be imposed for services at the NTSB Academy, with collected fees used to cover related costs. The Act also addresses the relinquishment of investigative priority in aircraft accidents and the assistance provided to victims and families by the Board and other agencies. Additionally, a revision of the 1977 agreement between the NTSB and the FBI is required within one year of the Act's enactment. The Federal Bureau of Investigation must update their 1977 agreement on accident investigations and submit it to relevant committees. The National Transportation Safety Board is granted relief from contracting requirements for investigation services until September 30, 2006, allowing expedited investigations without competition. The National Transportation Safety Board is required to report on contracts over $25,000 and justify any lack of competition. Additionally, there are provisions for appeals regarding accident and safety data classification and publication. The Board determines aircraft accidents, employees must notify owners of appeal rights. The Board establishes appeal procedures. This does not apply to accidents resulting in loss of life. The Secretary reports annually on safety recommendations status to Congress and the Board. The Board's recommendations on the 'most wanted list' must be reported by the Secretary annually until final action is taken. Failure to report by March 1 triggers notification to relevant Congressional committees. SEC. 7. TECHNICAL AMENDMENTS.
    Section 1131(a)(2) of title 49, United States Code, is amended by moving subparagraphs (B) and (C) 4 ems to the left.
SEC. 8. DOT INSPECTOR GENERAL INVESTIGATIVE AUTHORITY.
    Section 228 of the Motor Carrier Safety Improvement Act of 1999 is transferred to, and added at the end of, title 49, United States Code as section 354, granting investigative authority to the Inspector General. SEC. 9. REPORTS ON OPEN SAFETY RECOMMENDATIONS: The Secretary of Transportation must provide Congress and the National Transportation Safety Board with reports on the regulatory status of open safety recommendations, including those related to 15-passenger van safety, railroad grade crossing safety, and medical certifications for commercial driver's licenses. Updates must be given every two years until final regulatory action is taken. The Secretary of Transportation must provide Congress and the National Transportation Safety Board with reports on the regulatory status of open safety recommendations. If a report is not received within 30 days, the Board will notify the relevant committees in Congress.
